title: 111_hr3382
content: The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" or the "HIRE Act of 2009" aims to address the economic losses in the home furnishing and building products market. It highlights job losses and the need for targeted efforts to save and create jobs in this sector. The Act includes a deduction for purchases of personal use building products and home furnishings in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" allows individuals to deduct the cost of qualified building products and home furnishings purchased during the taxable year. The maximum deduction is $2,000 for joint returns and $1,000 for other cases, with a potential doubling of the limitation for products meeting environmental standards. The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" allows individuals to deduct the cost of qualified building products and home furnishings purchased during the taxable year. The deduction is subject to recognized environmental standards such as LEED, Green Globes, and Energy Star, or other widely recognized national or industry standards with a positive life cycle analysis. The dollar limitation under this act is adjusted based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The deduction under the "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" is subject to recognized environmental standards and is adjusted based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The deduction amount is reduced by a certain ratio of the taxpayer's income over a specified limitation, with different limits for joint returns and other cases. The term "modified adjusted gross income" excludes specific sections and is rounded to the nearest amount. The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" allows a deduction for qualified building products and home furnishings installed in the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction is subject to specific criteria and rounded to the nearest $10. The "Home Improvements Revitalize the Economy Act of 2009" allows a deduction for qualified building products and home furnishings installed in the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction excludes home electronics, home appliances, housewares, artwork, and property eligible for depreciation. Labor costs for onsite preparation and installation are included in the property cost. The deduction does not apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to accommodate this deduction. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. A new section, "Building Products and Home Furnishings," is added to the Internal Revenue Code for a credit on purchases of personal use building products and home furnishings. The tax code allows individuals a credit of 20% on the cost of qualified building products and home furnishings, up to $500 for joint filers ($250 for others). The credit is subject to adjusted gross income limitations and applies to purchases made after December 31, 2008. The tax code provides a 20% credit on qualified building products and home furnishings, with a maximum of $500 for joint filers ($250 for others). The credit is subject to adjusted gross income limitations and applies to purchases made after December 31, 2008. Labor costs related to onsite preparation, assembly, application, or original installation of the property are included in the cost calculation. No credit is allowed if a deduction under section 224 is claimed for the same year. This provision expires for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2011. The tax code offers a refundable credit for purchases of building products and home furnishings for resale, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. The tax code provides a credit of 10% of the cost for qualified building products and home furnishings purchased for resale, with a maximum credit of $10,000 per year. Qualified items are tangible personal property used in personal residences. This credit does not apply to certain types of property. Controlled groups are treated as a single employer for this credit. The credit is refundable and subject to special rules under section 38 and 39 of the tax code.
